rev.comment: restore 'corporate affairs and culture' section to earlier revision. New revisions had WAYYYY to much detail and non-notable cruft.
rev.diff:
Line 106: Line 106:
They have all declined recent offers of bonuses and increases in compensation by Google's board of directors. In a 2006 report of the United States' richest people, [[Forbes]] reported that [[Sergey Brin]] was #12 with a net worth of $14.1 billion, and [[Larry Page]] was #13 with a net worth of $14.0 billion.<ref>Miller, Matthew; Serafin, Tatiana. "[http://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/54/biz_06rich400_The-400-Richest-Americans_land.html The 400 Richest Americans]." ''[[Forbes]].'' [[September 21]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[November 26]], [[2006]].</ref>
They have all declined recent offers of bonuses and increases in compensation by Google's board of directors. In a 2006 report of the United States' richest people, [[Forbes]] reported that [[Sergey Brin]] was #12 with a net worth of $14.1 billion, and [[Larry Page]] was #13 with a net worth of $14.0 billion.<ref>Miller, Matthew; Serafin, Tatiana. "[http://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/54/biz_06rich400_The-400-Richest-Americans_land.html The 400 Richest Americans]." ''[[Forbes]].'' [[September 21]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[November 26]], [[2006]].</ref>
â
===Office Locations===
+
===Googleplex===
â   â
====Googleplex, Mountain View====
 
[[Image:Googleplexsouthsidesecondangle.jpg|thumb|right|The Googleplex]]
[[Image:Googleplexsouthsidesecondangle.jpg|thumb|right|The Googleplex]]
{{main|Googleplex}}
{{main|Googleplex}}
â
[[Image:Googleplex Welcome Sign.jpg|thumb|right|Sign at the Googleplex]]
 
As a play on Google's name, its headquarters, in Mountain View, California, is referred to as "the [[Googleplex]]" â a [[googolplex]] being 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the HQ being a [[complex]] of buildings (cf. [[movie theater|multiplex]], cineplex, etc). The lobby is decorated with a [[piano]], [[lava lamps]], old server clusters, and a projection of search queries on the wall. The hallways are full of exercise balls and [[bicycle]]s. Each employee has access to the corporate recreation center. Recreational amenities are scattered throughout the campus and include a workout room with weights and rowing machines, locker rooms, washers and dryers, a massage room, assorted [[video game]]s, [[Foosball]], a [[piano|baby grand piano]], a pool table, and [[ping pong]]. In addition to the [[Recreation room|rec room]], there are snack rooms stocked with various [[cereal]]s, [[gummy bear]]s, [[toffee]], [[licorice]], [[cashew]]s, [[yogurt]], [[carrot]]s, fresh fruit, and dozens of different drinks including fresh [[juice]], [[soft drink|soda]], and make your own [[cappuccino]].
As a play on Google's name, its headquarters, in Mountain View, California, is referred to as "the [[Googleplex]]" â a [[googolplex]] being 1 followed by a googol of zeros, and the HQ being a [[complex]] of buildings (cf. [[movie theater|multiplex]], cineplex, etc). The lobby is decorated with a [[piano]], [[lava lamps]], old server clusters, and a projection of search queries on the wall. The hallways are full of exercise balls and [[bicycle]]s. Each employee has access to the corporate recreation center. Recreational amenities are scattered throughout the campus and include a workout room with weights and rowing machines, locker rooms, washers and dryers, a massage room, assorted [[video game]]s, [[Foosball]], a [[piano|baby grand piano]], a pool table, and [[ping pong]]. In addition to the [[Recreation room|rec room]], there are snack rooms stocked with various [[cereal]]s, [[gummy bear]]s, [[toffee]], [[licorice]], [[cashew]]s, [[yogurt]], [[carrot]]s, fresh fruit, and dozens of different drinks including fresh [[juice]], [[soft drink|soda]], and make your own [[cappuccino]].
â
====111 8th Ave, New York City====
+
[[Image:Googleplex Welcome Sign.jpg|thumb|left|Sign at the Googleplex]]
â
In [[2006]], Google moved into 311,000 square feet of office space in [[New York City]], at 111 [[Eighth Avenue|Eighth Ave.]] in Manhattan.<ref name="manhattan">Reardon, Marguerite. "[http://news.com.com/2100-1024_3-6121970.html Google takes a bigger bite of Big Apple]." ''[http://www.cnet.com/ c net].'' [[October 2]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The office was specially designed and built for Google and houses its largest advertising sales team, which has been instrumental in securing large partnerships, most recently deals with [[MySpace]] and [[AOL]].<ref name="manhattan"/>. It is estimated that the building costs Google $10 million per year to rent and is similar in design and functionality to its [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View]] headquarters, including Foosball, air hockey, and ping-pong tables, as well as a video game area.<ref name="manhattan"/>
+
In 2006, Google moved into 311,000 square feet of office space in [[New York City]], at 111 [[Eighth Avenue|Eighth Ave.]] in Manhattan.<ref name="manhattan">Reardon, Marguerite. "[http://news.com.com/2100-1024_3-6121970.html Google takes a bigger bite of Big Apple]." ''[http://www.cnet.com/ c net].'' [[October 2]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 9]], [[2006]].</ref> The office was specially designed and built for Google and houses its largest advertising sales team, which has been instrumental in securing large partnerships, most recently deals with [[MySpace]] and [[AOL]].<ref name="manhattan"/> In 2003, they added an engineering staff in New York City, which has been responsible for more than 100 engineering projects, including [[Google Maps]], [[Google Spreadsheets]], and others.<ref name="manhattan"/> It is estimated that the building costs Google $10 million per year to rent and is similar in design and functionality to its [[Mountain View, California|Mountain View]] headquarters, including Foosball, air hockey, and ping-pong tables, as well as a video game area.<ref name="manhattan"/>
â
Since [[2003]], New York has also been home to engineering team which has been responsible for more than 100 projects, including [[Google Maps]], [[Google Spreadsheets]], and others.<ref name="manhattan"/>
+
Google is also making steps to insure that their operations are environmentally sound. In October 2006, the company announced plans to install thousands of [[solar panel]]s to provide up to 1.6 [[megawatt]]s of [[electricity]], enough to satisfy approximately 30% of the campus' energy needs.<ref name="solar">Richmond, Riva. "[http://www.marketwatch.com/News/Story/Story.aspx?dist=newsfinder&siteid=mktw&guid=%7B630082C7-5370-46C2-8041-FC3FCA28CA16%7D Google plans to build huge solar energy system for headquarters]." ''[http://www.marketwatch.com/ MarketWatch].'' [[October 17]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 17]], [[2006]].</ref> The system will be the largest solar power system constructed on a [[United States|U.S.]] corporate campus and one of the largest on any corporate site in the world.<ref name="solar"/> In June 2007, Google announced that they plan to become [[carbon neutral]] by [[2008]], which includes investing in energy efficiency, renewable energy sources, and purchasing carbon offsets, such as investing in projects like capturing and burning [[methane]] from animal waste at Mexican and Brazilian farms.<ref>Staff Writer. "[http://www.environmentalleader.com/2007/06/19/google-to-go-carbon-neutral-by-2008/ Google To Go Carbon Neutral By 2008]." ''[http://www.environmentalleader.com/ Environmental Leader].'' [[June 19]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[July 10]], [[2007]].</ref>
â   â
====395 Page Mill Road, Palo Alto====
  â
In July [[2007]], Google announced that they will be leasing [[Hewlett Packard]]'s original [[headquarters]] in [[Palo Alto]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_6355707|title=Google leases historic HP site|work=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|first=Katherine|last=Conrad|date=[[2007-07-12]]|accessdate=2007-07-13}}</ref>. The building has also served as the headquarters for [[Agilent Technologies]] for 6 years.
  â   â
It is 225,000 [[Square foot|square feet]] in size and can house 850 employees.
  â   â
===Environmentally-friendly operations===
  â
Google is also taking steps to ensure that their operations are environmentally sound. In October 2006, the company announced plans to install thousands of [[solar panel]]s to provide up to 1.6 [[megawatt]]s of [[electricity]], which is enough to satisfy approximately 30% of the campus' energy needs.<ref name="solar">Richmond, Riva. "[http://www.marketwatch.com/News/Story/Story.aspx?dist=newsfinder&siteid=mktw&guid=%7B630082C7-5370-46C2-8041-FC3FCA28CA16%7D Google plans to build huge solar energy system for headquarters]." ''[http://www.marketwatch.com/ MarketWatch].'' [[October 17]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 17]], [[2006]].</ref> This would be the largest solar powered system constructed on a [[United States|U.S.]] corporate campus and one of the largest on any corporate site in the world.<ref name="solar"/> In June 2007, the company announced that they plan to become [[carbon neutral]] by [[2008]], which includes investing in energy efficient and renewable energy sources, and purchasing [[carbon offsets]] - such as investing in projects like capturing and burning [[methane]] from [[animal waste]] at [[Mexico|Mexican]] and [[Brazil|Brazilian]] farms.<ref>Staff Writer. "[http://www.environmentalleader.com/2007/06/19/google-to-go-carbon-neutral-by-2008/ Google To Go Carbon Neutral By 2008]." ''[http://www.environmentalleader.com/ Environmental Leader].'' [[June 19]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[July 10]], [[2007]].</ref>
 
==="Twenty percent" time===
==="Twenty percent" time===
Line 126: Line 125:
Some thought the announcement of [[Gmail]] in 2004 around April Fool's Day (as well as the doubling of Gmail's storage space to two gigabytes in 2005) was a joke, although both of these turned out to be genuine announcements. In 2005, a comedic graph depicting Google's goal of "infinity plus one" GB of storage was featured on the [[Gmail]] homepage.
Some thought the announcement of [[Gmail]] in 2004 around April Fool's Day (as well as the doubling of Gmail's storage space to two gigabytes in 2005) was a joke, although both of these turned out to be genuine announcements. In 2005, a comedic graph depicting Google's goal of "infinity plus one" GB of storage was featured on the [[Gmail]] homepage.
â
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], âHackerâ (Actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 24]], [[2007]].</ref> In addition, the search engine calculator provides [[The Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 24]], [[2007]].</ref> Google also routinely modifies its logo in accordance with various holidays or special events throughout the year, such as [[Christmas]], [[Mother's Day]], or various [[birthday]]s of notable individuals.<ref name="google_holiday">"[http://www.google.com/intl/en/holidaylogos.html Holiday logos]." ''Google''. Retrieved on [[May 21]], [[2007]].</ref>
+
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], âHackerâ (Actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 24]], [[2007]].</ref> When asked how to get from a location in the U.S. to a location in Europe, Google Maps will provide directions that include an instruction to "Swim across the Atlantic Ocean." <ref name="atlantic">"[http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&saddr=North+America&daddr=Germany Google Maps]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on [[May 2]], [[2007]].</ref> In addition, the search engine calculator provides [[The Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''[[Google]].'' Retrieved on [[January 24]], [[2007]].</ref> Google also routinely modifies its logo in accordance with various holidays or special events throughout the year, such as [[Christmas]], [[Mother's Day]], or various [[birthday]]s of notable individuals.<ref name="google_holiday">"[http://www.google.com/intl/en/holidaylogos.html Holiday logos]." ''Google''. Retrieved on [[May 21]], [[2007]].</ref>
===IPO and culture===
===IPO and culture===
Line 132: Line 131:
However, many analysts are finding that as Google grows the company is becoming more "corporate". In 2005, articles in ''[[The New York Times]]'' and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, no evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref> In an effort to maintain the company's unique culture, Google has designated a Chief Culture Officer in 2006, who also serves as the Director of Human Resources. The purpose of the Chief Culture Officer is to develop and maintain the culture and work on ways to keep true to the core values that the company was founded on in the beginning â a flat organization, a lack of hierarchy, a collaborative environment.<ref name="CCO">Mills, Elinor. "[http://www.zdnet.com.au/insight/software/soa/Meet-Google-s-culture-czar/0,139023769,339275147,00.htm Meet Google's culture czar]." ''[[ZDNet]].'' [[April 30]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[April 30]], [[2007]].</ref>
However, many analysts are finding that as Google grows the company is becoming more "corporate". In 2005, articles in ''[[The New York Times]]'' and other sources began suggesting that Google had lost its anti-corporate, no evil philosophy.<ref>Rivlin, Gary. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/24/technology/24valley.html Relax, Bill Gates; It's Google's Turn as the Villain]." ''[[New York Times]].'' [[August 24]], [[2005]].</ref><ref>Gibson, Owen; Wray, Richard. "[http://www.smh.com.au/news/technology/search-giant-may-outgrow-its-fans/2005/08/25/1124562975596.html3001.asp Search giant may outgrow its fans]." ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]].'' [[August 25]], [[2005]].</ref> In an effort to maintain the company's unique culture, Google has designated a Chief Culture Officer in 2006, who also serves as the Director of Human Resources. The purpose of the Chief Culture Officer is to develop and maintain the culture and work on ways to keep true to the core values that the company was founded on in the beginning â a flat organization, a lack of hierarchy, a collaborative environment.<ref name="CCO">Mills, Elinor. "[http://www.zdnet.com.au/insight/software/soa/Meet-Google-s-culture-czar/0,139023769,339275147,00.htm Meet Google's culture czar]." ''[[ZDNet]].'' [[April 30]], [[2007]]. Retrieved on [[April 30]], [[2007]].</ref>
â   â
